title: Ticket #181: strerror()-like function for Win32 error codes
description: In some Win32-specific areas of the code, we respond to a Windows API call failing by printing out the numeric value of GetLastError(). This is mainly because FormatMessage() needs to be used to get a human-readable error message and it's interface is a bit clumsy. We should implement a wrapper for FormatMessage() that just takes the error code and converts it into a string, and use it from places in the code that currently print numeric error codes.
remarks:
2009-Mar-30 13:07:36 by mccardel:
Currently I have a small function written (but not tested). Trying to figure out what exactly needs to be done for making a function in Condor.

Also am trying to think of how to replace 288-some instances of the old method of outputting errors. I don't see a common thread between the way they are handled, so I can't easily use regexes.

2009-Apr-15 16:26:53 by mccardel:
Alright, here's the patch. Hopefully it's correct :)

Some notes: when you call the formatted message functions, you have to assign it to a string. After your use of it, you have to free it using LocalFree(), since the string is allocated using LocalAlloc() in a windows function that is called by getFormattedErrorMsg. This is done so it can be combined with dprintf().

A future project could be to make it so that the function accepts a va_list, and all the stuff that entails, so then the function would be fully self-contained. Right now I don't feel comfortable enough with that sort of thing though, and would probably have a few bugs.

2009-Jun-18 13:40:33 by mccardel:
Redid this because the way I did it before was, quite frankly, embarrassing and stupid. The new way is much better, and closely mimics dprintf in usage.
